courses.HIS 2A — The World to 1500:
Course: HIS 2A — The World to 1500
Credits: 5
Description: Surveys the rise of complex societies: the formation of classical civilizations in Afroeurasia and the Americas, post-classical empires and cross-cultural exchange, technology and environmental change, the Mongol Empire, and oceanic voyages and the origins of the modern world.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 2B — The World Since 1500:
Course: HIS 2B — The World Since 1500
Credits: 5
Description: Examines major world issues over the past 500 years. Topics include European expansion and colonialism, the Muslim empires, East Asia from Ming to Qing, the Americas, Africa, the scientific-technological revolution, decolonization, and modern environmental problems. Designed primarily for first- and second-year students, it provides a time frame for understanding events within a global framework.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 4 — History of the Present: Investig:
Course: HIS 4 — History of the Present: Investigating the Historical Origins of Contemporary Problems
Credits: 5
Description: This course answers big questions about the present state of the world by excavating their historical development. Each year, instructors identify four new contemporary questions to explore through lecture, podcasts, readings, and videos. Students learn historical methodologies, including gathering and evaluating evidence, and developing compelling arguments and narratives. Students use these skills to investigate questions that matter to them through a collaborative research project, learning that everything has a history, including the issues grabbing our attention right now.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 5B — Cult, Church, Empire: History o:
Course: HIS 5B — Cult, Church, Empire: History of Early Christianity, 0-431 C.E.
Credits: 5
Description: Christianity from its origins as a Jewish messianic movement, its expansion in multiple forms in the Greco-Roman world and the East, to its transformation into the major religion of the Roman and Byzantine empires. (Formerly offered as Early Christianity: First to Fourth Century A.D.)
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 5C — The Bible in History, Culture,:
Course: HIS 5C — The Bible in History, Culture, and Controversy
Credits: 5
Description: The Bible is a sacred text for Jews, Christians, and Muslims. It is also a cultural artifact of human history, preserving ancient debates about political and religious identity, slavery and immigration, sexual ethics, and environmental stewardship. What can we know about the Bible's origins and interpretations, the relationships between its texts and others, and the people who wrote it? Course introduces the history and literature of the Bible through close readings of famous portions in a manner that introduces literary-critical methodologies for the study of religion. (Formerly Introduction to the Bible.)
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 5D — Religions of Abraham:
Course: HIS 5D — Religions of Abraham
Credits: 5
Description: The phrase "Religions of Abraham" describes three religionsâJudaism, Christianity, and Islamâthat claim Abraham as chief patriarch. This course examines the formation of these diverse traditions chiefly through primary source material: literature, letters, and legal documents. The historical period of the ancient Near East from the height of the Babylonian Empire to the fall of the Umayyad Caliphate is covered, while students also learn about the variety of beliefs, texts, and practices that comprise these vibrant world religions.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 9 — Introduction to Native American:
Course: HIS 9 — Introduction to Native American History
Credits: 5
Description: Introduction to the interdisciplinary field of Native American Studies and the Indigenous experience. Topics include: history of United States-Indian relations; colonialism; sovereignty; identity; representation of Native Americans in popular culture; and contemporary efforts toward decolonization in indigenous communities.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 9C — California Indian History:
Course: HIS 9C — California Indian History
Credits: 5
Description: California encompasses the nation's largest Native population and the state's policies create a complex political and legal structure. This course provides a history of early California in the 18th and 19th centuries and a review of the urban Indian experience in the 20th century. The first part sets the historical foundation and traces early California Indian history. The second part shifts to 20th-century urban Indian issues and the contemporary moment for California Indian peoples. Covers topics such as Indian labor exploitation, genocide, termination, relocation, and federal recognition. (Formerly FMST 13.)
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 10A — United States History to 1877:
Course: HIS 10A — United States History to 1877
Credits: 5
Description: Focuses on the building of British American colonies and the establishment, disintegration, and reconstruction of the nation with an emphasis on how class, race, ethnicity, and gender impacted colonial development and structured the nation's agenda and the definition of citizenship.
Requirements: American History and Institutions Yes
courses.HIS 10B — United States History, 1877 to:
Course: HIS 10B — United States History, 1877 to 1977
Credits: 5
Description: Surveys the political, social, and cultural history of the United States from 1877 to 1977. Focuses on national politics with emphasis on how class, race, ethnicity, and gender changed the nation's agenda.
Requirements: American History and Institutions Yes
courses.HIS 11A — Latin America: Colonial Period:
Course: HIS 11A — Latin America: Colonial Period
Credits: 5
Description: Introduces the social, cultural, economic, and political history of the New World through a close examination of the process of European conquest in the 16th century and its consequences for both native and settler peoples. Medieval and Renaissance European and African backgrounds; Inca, Maya, Aztec, plains, woodland, and tropical rainforest native American societies; processes of military and cultural conquest; epidemics and ecological changes; native resistance and the establishment of the fundamental institutions of colonial society.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 11B — Latin America: National Period:
Course: HIS 11B — Latin America: National Period
Credits: 5
Description: An introduction to the study of Latin American history from the Independence Wars in the early 19th century to the present. Topics include changing economic models of development, U.S. role, rural and urban life, women, nationalisms, populism, revolution, the military in politics, and the problem of democracy.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 12 — Introduction to Latino American:
Course: HIS 12 — Introduction to Latino American History
Credits: 5
Description: Introduces students to the history of U.S. Latinos drawing on the experience of Central Americans, people of Mexican descent, Puerto Ricans, Dominican Americans, and Cuban Americans. Emphasizes international processes that fundamentally shape U.S. Latino communities.
Requirements: American History and Institutions Yes
courses.HIS 13 — Introduction to American Religi:
Course: HIS 13 — Introduction to American Religious Culture
Credits: 5
Description: Introduction to the many communities found within the American religious landscape, balancing extraordinary diversity characterizing American pluralism against the dominant religious culture. Proceeds historically, engaging major problems and developments including utopianism, the rise of evangelicalism, religion and reform, manifest destiny, secularization and modernity, and the intersection of politics and religion.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 15 — The United States of America fr:
Course: HIS 15 — The United States of America from its Founding through Our Time
Credits: 5
Description: Takes students through five critical moments in United States history: the American Revolution, the Civil War, the New Deal, the Civil Rights era, and the years following the attack on the United States on Sept. 11, 2001. Designed for non-majors.
Requirements: American History and Institutions Yes
courses.HIS 20 — U.S. Popular Music Movements:
Course: HIS 20 — U.S. Popular Music Movements
Credits: 5
Description: Focuses on the development of popular music genres in the United States and the social contexts that have produced them, from the 19th Century to the present. Promotes an understanding of how music influences and reflects our political lives.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 31A — African History to 1900:
Course: HIS 31A — African History to 1900
Credits: 5
Description: Introduces students to African History, from the very beginning of Homo sapiens to the dawn of European colonialism across the continent. In this long journey, we are guided by the contributions brought by Africanist historiography to history as a field of knowledge and to the public debate. Course considers the way we think of history, how it impacts non-Western societies, and how learning about the African past enables us to better understand the historical roots of our time. To achieve this, course looks attentively at African societies from within.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 32A — Islam in Africa and the Africa:
Course: HIS 32A — Islam in Africa and the African Diaspora
Credits: 5
Description: Introduces the History of Islam, its spread over Africa, and the role of the African diaspora in making Islam a global religion. Course delves into the role of African and African diasporic communities in globalizing Islam, and considers the relationship between Islam and local cultures to understand how religious unity and cultural diversity within Islam interact. It also aims to develop tools to interpret how race and ethnicity have been used by and applied to African Muslims within the global Muslim community.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 39D — Floods, Epidemics, and Famine::
Course: HIS 39D — Floods, Epidemics, and Famine: Environmental History of the Early Modern Atlantic World
Credits: 5
Description: Familiarizes undergraduates with environmental history as a discipline, as well as introduce them to the early modern period and the Atlantic World as a region of study by focusing on themes such as climate shifts and crises, the spread of epidemic disease, and the relationship between the environment and colonialism. Course does not assume previous experience with history courses and is intended to be a broad survey encompassing several regions of study. It is arranged both thematically and geographically and emphasizes environmental change throughout the early modern period to give a broad geographical overview of major environmental topics during the 15th through 18th centuries.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 39E — Monsters, Media, and the Histo:
Course: HIS 39E — Monsters, Media, and the History of the Supernatural in Modern Japan
Credits: 5
Description: Study of modern Japanese history from the late Edo period to the present day. Examines the cultural lives of monsters and transformations in meaning through major events in Japanese history. Examines the intellectual, cultural, and social histories of monsters and their entanglement with the emergence of science and folklore; the formation of the nation-state; racism, politics, and war; urbanization and kinship structures; and capitalism and virtual worlds.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 39F — Expansion, Power, and Change::
Course: HIS 39F — Expansion, Power, and Change: Christian World Missions and Missionaries
Credits: 5
Description: Course stretches students' reflections on the nature of Christian mission and the work of missionaries, their imbroglio with and involvement in state and society, and how historical sourcing may impact the way we see things, lives, and our past. Begins in the 1st century BCE where Christianity emerged in West Asia and is organized chronologically through the 21st century. Course examines Christianity's expansion and external power and the competing views of it as rebellious, revolutionary and justice-oriented momentum versus a repressive conversion institution working politically, militarily, and economically. Also examines how the perception and strategy of Christian mission changed in time, region, groups, and individual missionaries, and how Christian mission, as a power, contributed to the regional and global changes.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 39G — History in Action: Oral Histor:
Course: HIS 39G — History in Action: Oral History in Practice
Credits: 5
Description: Introduces the methodology of oral history as well as its varying applications for the public humanities. Students learn about the ethical, practical, and methodological strategies for creating an oral history project, as well as initiate at least their first interview by the end of the course.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 39H — U.S. Bases in Asia Pacific: Po:
Course: HIS 39H — U.S. Bases in Asia Pacific: Power, Pollution, and Protest
Credits: 5
Description: Survey of U.S. military bases and influence in the Asia Pacific Region since the end of the Second World War. Using the geographic scope of PACOM (Pacific Command), the course covers an area including Japan, Guam, Hawaiâi, and Korea. Despite the failure of President Obamaâs âPivot to the Pacificâ campaign, there remains a long history of U.S. presence in and across the Pacific Ocean; sometimes this presence is in the form of U.S. soldiers stationed on bases abroad, sometimes this presence is landscape altering in the form of nuclear testing. Students are introduced to key themes in the creation of âAmericaâs Lake,â as well as movements of resistance against the U.S. empire.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 39I — Social and Economic History of:
Course: HIS 39I — Social and Economic History of U.S.-Mexico Borderlands, 1848-Present
Credits: 5
Description: Examines the history of lived experiences and struggles throughout the U.S.-Mexico Borderlands since 1848. Examines the regionâs contested legacies of settler colonialism, border imperialism, and transnational resistance from the perspective of Indigenous communities, Mexican-descended peoples, and migrant laborers. Uses historical literature, film, and primary sources to assess how these communities have responded to the regionâs shifting borders and why it is significant in our contemporary political climate.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 40A — Early Modern East Asia:
Course: HIS 40A — Early Modern East Asia
Credits: 5
Description: Surveys the history of East Asia from 1500 to 1894. Covers political, social, economic, and cultural histories of China, Japan, and Korea with the goal of perceiving a regional history that encompassed each society.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 40B — The Making of Modern East Asia:
Course: HIS 40B — The Making of Modern East Asia
Credits: 5
Description: A broad introductory survey of the political, social, economic, philosophical, and religious heritage of modern China, Japan, and Korea. Emphasis on the historical foundations of modern nationalism, the colonial experience, and revolutionary movements.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 41 — The Making of the Modern Middle:
Course: HIS 41 — The Making of the Modern Middle East
Credits: 5
Description: History of the modern Middle East from 1800 to the present, with special reference to the 20th century and forces which have shaped the area. The impact of imperialism, nationalism, and revolution in the area, with particular attention to the history of four countries: Turkey, Iran, Egypt, Israel.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 44 — Modern South Asia, 1500 to Pres:
Course: HIS 44 — Modern South Asia, 1500 to Present
Credits: 5
Description: Provides an introductory survey of South Asian history and society from the beginning of the 16th Century until the dawn of the 21st Century. Students gain an understanding of major events and long transformations in society, economy, culture, and politics.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 50 — When Pharaohs Reigned: The Hist:
Course: HIS 50 — When Pharaohs Reigned: The History of Ancient Egypt
Credits: 5
Description: Introduces the political and social history of ancient Egyptian civilization from the Predynasitic through the end of the Pharaonic period. (Formerly Pyramids and Papyrus: the History of Ancient Egypt.)
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 51 — Pyramids of Earth: Religion and:
Course: HIS 51 — Pyramids of Earth: Religion and Symbol in the Ancient World
Credits: 5
Description: Investigates the use of the pyramid architectural form in ancient societies across the globe, including Egypt, Mesopotamia, the Americas, and Southeast Asia. The social, political, and religious motivation for building pyramids is explored.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 58 — From Pirates to Refugees: The H:
Course: HIS 58 — From Pirates to Refugees: The History of the Modern Mediterranean
Credits: 5
Description: Covers the history of the Mediterranean from the end of the Ottoman Empire to the present. It focuses on the role of empire in shaping patterns of economic and cultural exchange.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 61 — Classical Mythology:
Course: HIS 61 — Classical Mythology
Credits: 5
Description: Introduces the philosophy of myth, and surveys classical Greek mythology. Students explore the mythic mode of thinking and its distinguishing characteristics as well as the repertoire of Greek myths and their cultural contexts.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 62A — Classical World: Greece:
Course: HIS 62A — Classical World: Greece
Credits: 5
Description: An overview of Greek history from the beginnings through the Hellenistic period, with emphasis on the Archaic and Classical periods (ca. 800 B.C. through 323 B.C.).
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 62B — Classical World: Rome:
Course: HIS 62B — Classical World: Rome
Credits: 5
Description: A lecture course offering an overview of Roman history and civilization from the legendary founding of Rome in 753 B.C. to the collapse of the Roman Empire's central administration in the West in 476 A.D.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 65B — Plagues, Peasants, and Pirates:
Course: HIS 65B — Plagues, Peasants, and Pirates: Late Medieval Europe, 1000-1500
Credits: 5
Description: Reviews major social, political, economic, and cultural developments in Europe from 1000 to 1500 and themes including gender, warfare, ethnicity and religion, through primary sources and secondary readings. Primary focus is Western Europe: England, France, the Iberian Peninsula, the Holy Roman Empire, the Low Countries, and Italy. (Formerly Europe, 1000-1500.)
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 70A — Modern European History, 1500-:
Course: HIS 70A — Modern European History, 1500-1815
Credits: 5
Description: Surveys the economic, social, cultural, and political history of Europe since the late 15th century: 1500-1815. Course 70A is not a prerequisite to course 70B.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 70B — Modern European History, 1815-:
Course: HIS 70B — Modern European History, 1815-present
Credits: 5
Description: Surveys the political, social, and cultural history of Europe from the era of the Industrial Revolution to the beginning of the second millennium. Course 70A is not prerequisite to 70B.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 74 — Introduction to Jewish History:
Course: HIS 74 — Introduction to Jewish History and Cultures
Credits: 5
Description: Surveys 3,000 years of Jewish history. Themes include origins of the Jews in the ancient world, formation and persistence of the Jewish diaspora, coherence and diversity of Jewish experience, Jewish narrative and textual traditions, interaction between Jews and other cultures, productive tensions between tradition and modernity in Jewish history and literature.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 74A — Introduction to Middle Eastern:
Course: HIS 74A — Introduction to Middle Eastern and North African Jewish History: Ancient to Early Modern
Credits: 5
Description: Popular media present Muslims and Jews as age-old enemies; this is far from the truth. Through primary sources, secondary texts, and films, students examine this fraught and politicized history, challenging conventional narratives of the region and its Jewish population.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 74B — Introduction to Middle Eastern:
Course: HIS 74B — Introduction to Middle Eastern and North African Jewish History, 1500-2000
Credits: 5
Description: Surveys modern Jewish history from Morocco to Iran, 1500-2000. Studying these populations through original documents, scholarly works, and literature imparts a unique perspective on both modern Jewish history and that of the region, challenging and complementing standard narratives of each.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 74G — Graphic Novels and Jewish Hist:
Course: HIS 74G — Graphic Novels and Jewish History
Credits: 5
Description: Graphic novels are a powerful conduit for conveying historical information. Students examine a variety of graphic novels touching on Jewish historical themes and geographies, including: medieval Judeophobic persecution, crypto-Jews in the American southwest, a Sephardic boxing hero in 18th century London, the experiences of mid-20th century Algerian Jews under French colonial rule, the Holocaust both in Europe and as it touched North Africa, nostalgia for the Iraqi Jewish past, Jewish experiences in British Mandate Palestine, and more. Students gain in-depth contextualization for these works and themes, and become well-versed in major themes and debates in Jewish history.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 75 — Film and the Holocaust:
Course: HIS 75 — Film and the Holocaust
Credits: 5
Description: Examines a series of distinguished documentary and feature films about the destruction of European Jewry. Each film is placed in its historical context, and wherever possible, the readings include the original documents on which films were based. Emphasis is placed on the strategies the filmmakers used to address the problem of representing genocide without succumbing to mere melodrama.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 76 — Introduction to the Holocaust:
Course: HIS 76 — Introduction to the Holocaust
Credits: 5
Description: Investigates the genocide of the Jews from 1933 to 1945 within its broader historical context, including anti-Semitism, the Great Depression, Nazi-Soviet relations, and World War II. Examines how the Holocaust unfolded in Europe as well as its impact on Jews in North Africa and the Middle East. (Formerly The Holocaust: A Global Perspective.)
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 78 — Modern Authoritarianism in Euro:
Course: HIS 78 — Modern Authoritarianism in Europe and Beyond
Credits: 5
Description: Examines modern authoritarianism and mass dictatorship as distinct political forms that promote and draw their strength from popular support and mobilization. Students study how non-democratic leaders are able to attain, exercise, perpetuate, and misuse their power.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 80C — Global China:
Course: HIS 80C — Global China
Credits: 5
Description: Introductory and collaborative history course that examines the social dimensions of globalization through a focus on China since 1500. Asking how China shaped and was shaped by interactions with major world regionsâEurope, the Americas, and Asiaâcourse discusses how networks of trade, imperialism, revolutions, migration, popular culture, and capitalism created significant global conjunctures and interdependencies with lasting impact. In addition, course offers instruction on how to collaborate with others effectively to achieve common goals. Students apply knowledge and techniques learned to a series of group projects.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 80D — Visualizing Modern East Asia:
Course: HIS 80D — Visualizing Modern East Asia
Credits: 5
Description: Introduction to modern East Asian history, with a specific focus on the nations of China, Japan, and Korea. Students investigate major historical questions about modernity, imperialism, colonialism, nationalism, gender, and labor from the late 19th century to the late 20th century. This course is also designed to explore contemporary media, looking at how visual reproductions become instruments to remember the past. Through the exercise of visualizing East Asian history, the course aims to help students make critical assessments of mass media information on East Asia available to the American public.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 80X — History of the Modern Civil Ri:
Course: HIS 80X — History of the Modern Civil Rights Movement
Credits: 5
Description: The civil rights movement of the 1950s and 1960s, also referred to as the Second Reconstruction, was one of the most consequential periods in United States history. This course examines the many facets of the movement, focusing on the strategies, grassroots campaigns, and the many rank-and-file women and men who fought for freedom, liberation, and justice. (Formerly Civil Rights Movement: Grassroots Change and American Society.)
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 80Y — World War II Memories in the U:
Course: HIS 80Y — World War II Memories in the U.S. and Japan
Credits: 5
Description: Examines how the meaning of such issues as war origins, war responsibility, the atomic bomb, reparations, and racism have been subjects of contention in postwar U.S. and Japan. Students explore the relations between history, memory, and contemporary politics.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 81 — Science in the Colonial World:
Course: HIS 81 — Science in the Colonial World
Credits: 5
Description: Introduces students to the history of science in colonized lands. Covers topics such as natural history collecting, medicine, bodily experimentation, botanical gardens, healing plants, and agriculture. Students learn about local colonial scientific production and anti-colonial resistance by focusing on case studies from Southeast Asia, with supplemental readings on colonial Caribbean, Latin American, and North African sites, as well as present-day North American indigenous territories. Students also investigate the possibilities for decolonizing science itself.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 82 — California Gold Rush in Global:
Course: HIS 82 — California Gold Rush in Global History
Credits: 5
Description: Course seeks to reframe a paradigmatic event in the history of California and the United States as an event in global history. Rather than assume the spatial and temporal boundaries of the Gold Rush, students explore different possible answers to the questions of where and when the Gold Rush happened, why it matters, and for whom. Students retrace connections and make comparisons between events in California and other places that often fall beyond the purview of "California History" as conventionally understood. (Formerly Global History of the California Gold Rush.)
Requirements: American History and Institutions Yes
courses.HIS 90A — Nuclear Pacific:
Course: HIS 90A — Nuclear Pacific
Credits: 5
Description: Examines the history of nuclear weapons development, nuclear weapons use, nuclear testing, and nuclear power in the Pacific region from 1942 to the present. Students do research on nuclear science, medicine, energy, and weapons testing and their social, political, demographic, and environmental impacts.
Requirements: American History and Institutions Yes
courses.HIS 99 — Tutorial:
Course: HIS 99 — Tutorial
Credits: 5
Description: Students submit petition to sponsoring agency.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.HIS 100 — Historical Skills and Methods:
Course: HIS 100 — Historical Skills and Methods
Credits: 5
Description: Designed to introduce history majors to historical methods and provide preparation for exit seminars. Students develop critical reading, historical analysis, research, and disciplinary writing skills.
Requirements: Requirements Enrollment is restricted to proposed and declared history majors, or by permission of the instructor.
courses.HIS 101C — Oceans in World History:
Course: HIS 101C — Oceans in World History
Credits: 5
Description: Oceans, human communities, and the variety of relations between societies have been linked closely in world history. This course focuses on the three most well-researched and, historically, most important oceanic worlds--those that developed to link the regions bordering the Mediterranean Sea, Indian Ocean, and Atlantic Ocean.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 139M — Murderers, Witches, and Rebel:
Course: HIS 139M — Murderers, Witches, and Rebels: Depicting Difference in Colonial Latin America
Credits: 5
Description: Familiarizes students with depictions and descriptions of identity during the colonial period in the Spanish Americas across four major regions: Central Mexico, the YucatÃ¡n Peninsula, Peru, and New Mexico. Themes such as the casta system, Indigenous survivance and resistance, the changing role of women in public and private spheres, the role of Black confraternities and slave rebellions. The ways society became increasingly diverse in terms of class, gender, and race are highlighted, as well as the impact of invasion, subsequent military violence, and how colonial legal system impacted communities. Students examine how different identities emerged and how they experienced conflict and transformation as a result of political, social, cultural, economic, and religious change.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 186A — Public History Workshop:
Course: HIS 186A — Public History Workshop
Credits: 5
Description: From podcasts to museum exhibitions, public history takes many forms. This course gives students hands-on experience creating a public-history project designed to meet the needs of a community organization. Each iteration of the course focuses on a different project and community partner.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 101D — World History of Science:
Course: HIS 101D — World History of Science
Credits: 5
Description: Human curiosity and inquiry changed and varied widely across Eurasia. This course surveys how the curiosity and inquiry were framed in three major civilizations (China, Islam and Judeo-Christian) from the Mongol conquest of Eurasia in the 13th century to the beginning of industrial capitalism in the 19th century.
Requirements: Requirements Enrollment is restricted to sophomores, juniors, and seniors.
courses.HIS 101E — Global 1930s:
Course: HIS 101E — Global 1930s
Credits: 5
Description: Explores the turbulent 1930s from a global perspective. Students consider the great events of the decade--the Great Depression, the consolidation of communism, and the rise of fascism--within the context of global connections and forces, including those fostered by imperialism and various forms of internationalism. (Formerly course 196A.)
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 101F — Global Environmental History:
Course: HIS 101F — Global Environmental History
Credits: 5
Description: Provides overview of global environmental history from prehistoric times to the present. Explores how Homo Sapiens became the dominant species on the planet, how some of them managed to grow food and domesticate animals, and how these agrarian or nomadic societies developed states or even empires. Explores what many have called the Anthropocene Epoch in the evolution of Earth.
Requirements: Requirements Enrollment is restricted to sophomores, juniors, and seniors.
courses.HIS 101H — The Horse in World History:
Course: HIS 101H — The Horse in World History
Credits: 5
Description: Before the 20th century, the horse was, for humans, the most important animal: quickening the pace of travel; facilitating hunting and herding; providing traction for agriculture and industry; enabling the formation of cavalries that projected military power. The horse and rider became the subject of powerful myths, from the Arthurian legends of the Middle Ages through the American Western of our own time. Only with the advent of modern engines and motors did role of the horse begin to recede in human history. Course examines the human/equine partnership over a period of 6,000 years, from the beginning of domestication to the middle of the 20th century.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 103C — New Religious Movements:
Course: HIS 103C — New Religious Movements
Credits: 5
Description: Course offers a deep exploration of New Religious Movements, both ancient and modern. How are New Religious Movements born? What determines whether they grow, thrive, or die? How do they interpret the past to create new theologies? Students read sources from a variety of movements, from the UFO-based Raelian movement to the Gnostic Church, alongside appropriate secondary literature. In teams, students also select a NRM to study in depth throughout the quarter and present their research at the end of the course.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 104C — Celluloid Natives: American I:
Course: HIS 104C — Celluloid Natives: American Indian History on Film
Credits: 5
Description: Examines how American Indian history and culture has been portrayed in Hollywood films, with an emphasis on films that represent Native Americans over the broad spectrum of Native American/white relations.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 104D — Museums and the Representatio:
Course: HIS 104D — Museums and the Representation of Native American History, Memory, and Culture
Credits: 5
Description: Provides an historical overview of the relationship between American Indians and museums. Current issues and practices in museums are explored, primarily those associated with ethics, collecting practices, exhibitions, education/interpretation, and administration/governance.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 105 — Nations and Nationalism:
Course: HIS 105 — Nations and Nationalism
Credits: 5
Description: Provides an historical, comparative, and theoretical exploration of the development of nations and nationalism. Emphases include the historical formation of nation-states, modernization, colonialism, decolonization, nations and globalization, and the intersections between ethnicity, race, religions, and nationalism.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 106A — Vietnam War Memories:
Course: HIS 106A — Vietnam War Memories
Credits: 5
Description: Compares memories and interpretations of war in Southeast Asia by diverse groups in France, America, and Vietnam. Topics include war origins, military strategies, propaganda, combat, civilians, media, activism, MIAs, refugees, mixed race children, memorials, textbooks, films, music, literature, and art.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 106B — Asian and Asian American Hist:
Course: HIS 106B — Asian and Asian American History, 1941-Present
Credits: 5
Description: Analyzes immigration, race relations, war, gender ideology, family life, acculturation, political activism, interracial marriage, multiracial identity, and cultural representations between 1941 and the present. Emphasis on discussion, writing, research, and group presentations.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 109A — Race, Gender, and Power in th:
Course: HIS 109A — Race, Gender, and Power in the Antebellum South
Credits: 5
Description: Examines how ideologies of race and gender shaped the development of slavery and empire in the American South from European colonization to the eve of the American Civil War.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 110A — Colonial America, 1500-1750:
Course: HIS 110A — Colonial America, 1500-1750
Credits: 5
Description: Explores the social, economic, cultural, and political development of British North America from the first European/Amerindian contacts in the late 16th century through the establishment of a provincial British colonial society. Course 110A is not a prerequisite to course 110B.
Requirements: American History and Institutions Yes
courses.HIS 110B — Revolutionary America, 1740-1:
Course: HIS 110B — Revolutionary America, 1740-1815
Credits: 5
Description: Explores the political, social, economic, and cultural development of British North America from the first stirrings of resistance to the establishment of the U.S. Course 110A is not a prerequisite to course 110B.
Requirements: American History and Institutions Yes
courses.HIS 110D — The Civil War Era:
Course: HIS 110D — The Civil War Era
Credits: 5
Description: Social, political, and economic history of the American Civil War and Reconstruction, focusing on the war's changing nature and significance, emancipation, and the postwar struggle over the future of the South and the nation.
Requirements: American History and Institutions Yes
courses.HIS 110E — Rise of the Machines: Technol:
Course: HIS 110E — Rise of the Machines: Technology, Inequality, and the United States, 1877 to 1914
Credits: 5
Description: History of the U.S. during what was perhaps its most socially turbulent era, the period following Reconstruction through the First World War. What did it mean to be a nation in the post-Reconstruction era? How did a country that had only recently unified itself under one system of labor now resolve the question of national identity? Was America truly a nation by 1914?
Requirements: American History and Institutions Yes
courses.HIS 110F — World War USA: The United Sta:
Course: HIS 110F — World War USA: The United States from 1914 through 1945
Credits: 5
Description: Between the First and Second World Wars, American society accepted the need for a regulatory state to save capitalism from itself. Takes an in-depth look at many aspects of U.S. politics and culture during these years.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 110G — Strange Days: The USA and its:
Course: HIS 110G — Strange Days: The USA and its National Security State, 1945-1991
Credits: 5
Description: From the Good War to the Cold War, the Sixties to the rise of the New Right, the post-1945 American experience has been one of extremes. This survey course looks for evidence of commonality during those times. (Formerly Age of Extremes: The United States During the Cold War, 1945 to 1991)
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 110H — Greater Reconstruction: Race,:
Course: HIS 110H — Greater Reconstruction: Race, Empire, and Citizenship in the Post-Civil War United States
Credits: 5
Description: Examines how the consolidation of United States sovereignty in North America and the establishment of an overseas empire during the period between the conclusion of the Civil War and the Phillippine-American War reshaped conceptions of race and citizenship.
Requirements: American History and Institutions Yes
courses.HIS 112 — American Feminist Thought, 175:
Course: HIS 112 — American Feminist Thought, 1750-1950
Credits: 5
Description: Traces history of feminist thought in the United States from the 18th century Enlightenment to the mid-20th century. Focusing on questions of social identity, gender difference, and legal/political status, examines writings of philosophers, activists, novelists, and ordinary women that challenged religious, political, and scientific beliefs underlying gender inequality.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 113C — Women and American Religious:
Course: HIS 113C — Women and American Religious Culture
Credits: 5
Description: Historical introduction to religious culture of U.S. as experienced and created by women. Explores religious ideas about women, the treatment of women by mainstream institutions and religio-social communities, and female religious leaders and followers. Takes an explicitly feminist analytical approach and uses a variety of texts, including historical and literary scholarship, sacred texts, fiction, autobiography, material artifacts, visual art, and music.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 114 — Market Revolution in Antebellu:
Course: HIS 114 — Market Revolution in Antebellum U.S.
Credits: 5
Description: Examines the cultural, political, and environmental upheaval associated with antebellum market revolution. Topics include: markets and U.S. territorial expansion; reform movements that coalesced around disputes over what should, and should not be sold (e.g., antislavery activism; anti-prostitution reform movements).
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 116 — Slavery Across the Americas:
Course: HIS 116 — Slavery Across the Americas
Credits: 5
Description: Examines the exploitation of African people as slaves throughout European colonies in the Americas. How did slavery affect slaves, enslavers, and their societies? Emphasizes the diversity of slave regimes and their importance for shaping American life for all.
Requirements: American History and Institutions Yes
courses.HIS 116A — Unchained Memory: Slavery and:
Course: HIS 116A — Unchained Memory: Slavery and the Politics of the Past
Credits: 5
Description: Investigates the representation of slavery with scholarly and vernacual histories, focusing on the United States. Students examine representations of slavery in scholarly works, public-history venues like museums and historic sites, popular culture, and artistic productions. Students develop their own scholarly research into the history of slavery grounded in primary and secondary sources.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 117 — Wired Nation: Broadcasting & T:
Course: HIS 117 — Wired Nation: Broadcasting & Telecommunications in the US from the Telegraph to the Internet
Credits: 5
Description: Explores the history of telecommunications systems in the US starting with the telegraph, the telephone, wireless telegraph, radio, television and the Internet. Students learn about the development of these systems and the cultures that they foster.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 117A — From the Player Piano to Pand:
Course: HIS 117A — From the Player Piano to Pandora
Credits: 5
Description: Explores the history, culture, and politics of the distribution of recorded and live sound from the 1870s through the present.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 118 — The Global Cold War, 1945-1991:
Course: HIS 118 — The Global Cold War, 1945-1991
Credits: 5
Description: Explores the history of the Cold War from a global, multinational perspective. Begins with the opening salvos between the United States and the Soviet Union in 1945, and concludes with the collapse of the latter empire in 1991.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 118A — Conspiracy Planet: How Conspi:
Course: HIS 118A — Conspiracy Planet: How Conspiracies, Conspiracy Theories, and Conspiracy Scandals Shape History
Credits: 5
Description: Explores the history of a principal obsession of our age: the conspiracy. Focuses on the people who love them most: conspiracy theorists. Millions of people around the world believe in conspiracy theories. Why?
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 119 — Indigenous Feminisms:
Course: HIS 119 — Indigenous Feminisms
Credits: 5
Description: Explores issues central to Indigenous women's life experiences and Native feminist thought. Students consider the concerns and methodologies of Native feminismsâtheories and actions that highlight how settler colonialism is a fundamentally gendered process. Engages in foundational discussions of Native feminisms, settler colonial theory, and feminist methodologies. Course content focuses on communities in settler states currently known as the U.S. and Canada. Covers topics such as reproductive justice, gendered violence, cultural reclamation, and rematriation. (Formerly FMST 119.)
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 120 — W.E.B. Du Bois:
Course: HIS 120 — W.E.B. Du Bois
Credits: 5
Description: Examines the thought and activities of W.E.B. Du Bois across changing historical circumstances. Considers the ways Du Bois's work has been used in the present to address issues such as racism and imperialism.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 121A — African American History to 1:
Course: HIS 121A — African American History to 1877
Credits: 5
Description: Surveys the history and freedom struggle of African Americans from early beginnings in indigenous Africa to the end of Reconstruction. Topics include the North American colonization project, the transatlantic and domestic slave trade, seasoning, slavery and abolitionism, womenâs resistance, the Civil War, and post-emancipation.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 121B — African American History, 187:
Course: HIS 121B — African American History, 1877 to the Present
Credits: 5
Description: Surveys the history of African Americans from the post-Reconstruction and Jim Crow era to the present. Topics include northern and westward migration, womenâs suffrage and activism, the world wars, black nationalism, the Harlem Renaissance, the Great Depression, the Civil Rights and Black Power Movements, and black activism in contemporary America. (Formerly African American History: 1877 to the Present.)
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 122A — Jazz and United States Cultur:
Course: HIS 122A — Jazz and United States Cultural History, 1900-1945
Credits: 5
Description: Explores the meaning of jazz in United States society and as a U.S.-based art form in other societies. Examines the social and cultural forces that have produced different jazz styles and the various ways that social conflicts and ideals have been displaced onto the music.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 122B — Jazz and United States Cultur:
Course: HIS 122B — Jazz and United States Cultural History, 1945 to the Present
Credits: 5
Description: Explores the meaning of jazz in United States society and as a U.S.-based art form in other societies since 1945. Examines the social and cultural forces producing jazz movements and the social transformations, conflicts, and ideals read into the music.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 123 — Immigrants and Immigration in:
Course: HIS 123 — Immigrants and Immigration in U.S. History
Credits: 5
Description: Introduces U.S. immigration history from the colonial era to the present, with emphasis on the recent past. Particular attention given to changing immigration patterns; the character of the immigrant experience; and the range of responses to immigration, including nativism.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 124A — Panama Canal and U.S. Empire:
Course: HIS 124A — Panama Canal and U.S. Empire
Credits: 5
Description: Explores the technological, environmental, social, political, and diplomatic history of a critical link in global transportation networks: the Panama Canal. The Canal has long been celebrated as one of the great triumphs in the history of technology and engineering. But this triumphalism obscures a more complicated history of struggle over issues including land, water, health, race, citizenship, and sovereignty. Course explores the Panama Canal’s fraught history from the construction years of 1904-1914 through the restoration of full control to Panama in 1999.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 128 — Chicana/Chicano History:
Course: HIS 128 — Chicana/Chicano History
Credits: 5
Description: A survey course on the social history of the Mexican (Chicana/o) community and people in the U.S. through the 20th century. Themes include resistance, migration, labor, urbanization, culture and politics.
Requirements: American History and Institutions Yes
courses.HIS 130 — History of Modern Cuba:
Course: HIS 130 — History of Modern Cuba
Credits: 5
Description: Covers from the Cuban sugar revolution (late 18th century) to the socialist revolution and its aftermath (1959âpresent). It is intended to be not only a modern history of Cuba but also a broader history of Latin America through the case of Cuba.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 131 — Women in Colonial Latin Americ:
Course: HIS 131 — Women in Colonial Latin America
Credits: 5
Description: Introduction to the social history of Latin America through a focus on the inflections of class and ethnicity on gender in this region. First six weeks focuses on the colonial period. The last three weeks covers the 19th and 20th centuries.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 134A — Colonial Mexico:
Course: HIS 134A — Colonial Mexico
Credits: 5
Description: Covers the social, cultural, economic, and political history of colonial Mexico (New Spain). Special attention paid to colonial identity formation, religion, and labor systems. Begins by examining indigenous societies prior to the arrival of Europeans and concludes with Mexico's independence movement in the early 19th century.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 134B — History of Mexico, 1850 to Pr:
Course: HIS 134B — History of Mexico, 1850 to Present
Credits: 5
Description: Social, cultural, economic, and political history from the triumph of Liberalism to the present day, focusing on four key periods: the dictatorship of Porfirio Diaz (1900â1910), the armed phase of the Revolution (1910â1920), the consolidation of revolutionary programs and a single-party democracy (1920â1940), and the developmentalist counter-revolution since 1940. Provides background for understanding the Mexican diaspora to the U.S.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 137E — Literary Culture in Africa:
Course: HIS 137E — Literary Culture in Africa
Credits: 5
Description: Introduces students to textual culture in Islamic Africa, its libraries and current archives, discusses strategies employed by African authors to make their writings more effective in producing social and political outcomes, and analyzes texts beyond their informational surface, delving into their social and cultural contexts.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 139C — Queer Pasts: A Radical Tellin:
Course: HIS 139C — Queer Pasts: A Radical Telling of LGBTQ History in the United States
Credits: 5
Description: Critically explores how to preserve, represent, and study the history of queer and gender non-conforming people. Focuses on non-traditional and digital archives, oral history, and original research.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 139G — Herbs, Potions, and Viruses::
Course: HIS 139G — Herbs, Potions, and Viruses: History of Medicine and Public Health in Modern China
Credits: 5
Description: Introduction to the history of medicine and public health in China (primarily the 20th century) to help students gain a sense of modern Chinese history and make sense of the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. Reviews how the pandemic has fundamentally changed life, including discussions of state governance and the public health system and the allocation of medical resources and the role of Traditional Medicine (TCM). Surveys the historical development of medicine in 20th-century China, focusing on the dissemination of Western medicine, the evolvement of TCM, and the development of the public health system. Reviews the 1911 Manchurian plague, the cholera pandemic in the 1960s, the 2002 SARS outbreak, and the present-day COVID-19 pandemic.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 139J — Britain Made Digital: A Histo:
Course: HIS 139J — Britain Made Digital: A History of the Nation and its Empire
Credits: 5
Description: Examines modern British history from the consolidation of the British Isles into one United Kingdom to the divisions highlighted by the Brexit vote. Course weaves between domestic Britain and its empire, demonstrating their interrelatedness and dependence and touches on a wide area of the globe and the experiences of many peoples aside from the British. Course also aims to give students a full introduction to digital public history projects. Students asked at several stages of the course to critically examine how the presentation of historical material is affected by digital content, different media types, and engagement with various audiences.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 139L — A More Perfect Union:
Course: HIS 139L — A More Perfect Union
Credits: 5
Description: Presents an introduction to the history of the federal government and its handling of racism and civil rights during the 20th century. Course content is delivered through bi-weekly lectures along with an occasional seminar discussion of assigned readings. The goal of this class is to provide students with an understanding of how the United States evolved over the course of the 20th century and how government expansion was both influenced by and transformed institutional racism. Likewise, this class emphasizes the role of class, gender, and racial politics in steering the course of federal policies.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 140B — History of Qing China, 1644-1:
Course: HIS 140B — History of Qing China, 1644-1911
Credits: 5
Description: Introduces students to how Qing China arose, expanded, and struggled to enter the modern world. Focuses on what the Qing empire had in common with other agrarian empires across Eurasia, commercialization and communication networks, elite mobility and peasant revolts, political legitimacy of the alien rule, maintaining social order (such as merchants' control and gender segregation), massive population growth and internal migration, as well as its conflicts with the industrial West.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 140C — Revolutionary China 1895-1960:
Course: HIS 140C — Revolutionary China 1895-1960
Credits: 5
Description: Explores history of China from the late 19th century to the early years of the People's Republic, focusing on the end of imperial rule, the sources and development of revolution, and early attempts at at socialist transformation.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 140D — Recent Chinese History:
Course: HIS 140D — Recent Chinese History
Credits: 5
Description: Explores history of China from establishment of the People's Republic of China to the present, focusing on competing strategies of socialist transformation, urban/rural relations, and the effects of the post-Mao economic reforms.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 140E — Women in China's Long 20th Ce:
Course: HIS 140E — Women in China's Long 20th Century
Credits: 5
Description: Introduces changes in Chinese women's lives--and changes in shared social ideas about what women should do and be--from the mid-19th century to the present. When we foreground gender as a category of analysis, how does history look different?
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 142 — History of Hong Kong and Taiwa:
Course: HIS 142 — History of Hong Kong and Taiwan: Two Peripheries of China
Credits: 5
Description: Studies the history of two peripheries of China, Hong Kong and Taiwan, from the earliest written records to the present. These two places were at various times part of China, and, to some, are still parts of China. However, these two have historical trajectories distinct from China and have developed their unique positions in the world. This course invites students to think about Taiwan and Hong Kong, not only their local histories and development, but also their role as two peripheries of China in Chinese nationalism and in U.S-China relations.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 143B — History of the Philippines, 1:
Course: HIS 143B — History of the Philippines, 1815 to the Present
Credits: 5
Description: Examines Philippine history from the early 19th century through the present. Though the course timeline begins in the Spanish colonial period, the class interrogates understandings of the pre-colonial past and how these have informed Philippine nationalism, intellectual history, social sciences, and more. Students learn about debates in the field and become familiar with scholarship from the Philippines. Students also reflect on the political urgency of the contemporary moment and how transnational flows of migrants, activism, and cultural production have changed dominant approaches to historical studies on the archipelago.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 146A — Colonial South Asia 1750-1947:
Course: HIS 146A — Colonial South Asia 1750-1947
Credits: 5
Description: Introduces key transformations--political, economic, social, and cultural--in colonial Indian history. The focus is on the processes, institutions, and ideas that shaped colonial power and resisted it.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 147A — History of Premodern India:
Course: HIS 147A — History of Premodern India
Credits: 5
Description: A study of religions (Vaisnavism, Tantrism, Islam, Sikhism), art, literature, and social movements in their historical contexts from 1000 A.D. to 1800.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 147B — Political and Social History:
Course: HIS 147B — Political and Social History of Modern South Asia
Credits: 5
Description: Social, political, and religious movements in the colonial and postcolonial contexts of the 19th and 20th centuries in modern and contemporary South Asia.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 147C — South Asia in the 20th Centur:
Course: HIS 147C — South Asia in the 20th Century
Credits: 5
Description: Introduces historical change in 20th-century South Asia. Topics include: modernity, gender, state formation, nationalism, democracy, and development. Course material includes interdisciplinary secondary works, primary reading by important political actors, and films. Prior knowledge of South Asia is useful, but not necessary.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 147D — Intellectual History of South:
Course: HIS 147D — Intellectual History of South Asia
Credits: 5
Description: Highlights the power of ideas in making South Asia modern. Focuses on the 19th and 20th Centuries. Ideas assessed include liberalism, Marxism, Hindu revivalism, Islamic jihad,democracy, nationalism, secularism, and development.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 147E — Imperial Sport: Cricket in So:
Course: HIS 147E — Imperial Sport: Cricket in South Asia, 1800s to the Present
Credits: 5
Description: Examines cricket's history as an imperial sport for princes and merchants of South Asia and its use to socialize with and eventually compete with British colonial officials. Also studies its emergence among middle and lower classes and how religion, ethnicity, and cultural identities played an important role in the composition of cricket teams, and how these identities contributed to and were shaped by political movements, including the partitioning of South Asia. Also studies how cricketers and administrators were embroiled in the underground economy of betting and match fixing.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 149 — Plants, People, and the Making:
Course: HIS 149 — Plants, People, and the Making of Modern Southeast Asia
Credits: 5
Description: Analyzes the entangled history of plants and people in Southeast Asia. Provides a broad sweep of the early modern period (pre-1500), imperial contact, anti-colonialism, nationalism, and decolonization up to present-day social and political conditions. The class examines plants of agricultural and medicinal value, political importance and ritual meaning. Students also consider how plants can be historical agents that shape and influence interaction in the region. Students likewise learn about the emergence of Southeast Asia as a field of study in the United States and debate the intellectual legitimacy of area studies, particularly through the optic of plant life.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 149F — Southeast Asian Histories, So:
Course: HIS 149F — Southeast Asian Histories, Societies and Politics in Nine Tasty Foods
Credits: 5
Description: Examines political, cultural, and historical dynamics in Southeast Asia from the early modern period to the present. Students explore canonical reading and some of the most influential theories of Southeast Asian studies through animal and plant life that have gastronomically served the region for centuries. This approach leads students to recognize the utility of interdisciplinary investigation and to consider how fields such as ecology, zoology, and maritime studies have been impacted by methodologically creative work in the humanities and social sciences on the region.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 150A — Emperors and Outcasts: Ancien:
Course: HIS 150A — Emperors and Outcasts: Ancient Japan
Credits: 5
Description: Surveys the history of the peoples of the Japanese islands from prehistorical migrations through the 15th century. Emphases include examination of social structures, political formations, cultural production, and religion. (Formerly Ancient Japan.)
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 150B — Tokugawa Japan:
Course: HIS 150B — Tokugawa Japan
Credits: 5
Description: Surveys the history of the peoples of the Japanese islands from the middle of the 15th century to the middle of the 19th century. Focus is on the era of civil war, the formation of the early modern federated state, social structure, and cultural production.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 150C — Inventing Modern Japan: The S:
Course: HIS 150C — Inventing Modern Japan: The State and the People
Credits: 5
Description: Surveys the history of the peoples of the modern Japanese nation from the Meiji Restoration to the present. Focuses on the formation of the modern state, empire, social movements, and cultural production. (Formerly Modern Japan.)
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 150D — The Japanese Empire, 1868-194:
Course: HIS 150D — The Japanese Empire, 1868-1945
Credits: 5
Description: Examines the history of the Japanese colonial empire from 1868 to 1945, including the colonies of Taiwan, Korea, Micronesia, and Manchuria. Considers how the colonies were ruled and what the legacies of the empire have been.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 150E — History and Memory in the Oki:
Course: HIS 150E — History and Memory in the Okinawan Islands
Credits: 5
Description: Known historically as the Ryukyu Islands, Okinawa has long been an important transmitter of people, ideas, and goods in East Asia. Course explores this history by focusing not only on the royalty of these islands, but also on the lives of everyday people.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 150F — Engendering Empires: Women in:
Course: HIS 150F — Engendering Empires: Women in Modern Japan and Korea
Credits: 5
Description: Explores how women's experiences in Japan and Korea were intertwined and differentiated before and during World War II under Japanese empire, and from the postwar to the present under American hegemony.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 150G — History of Disabilities in Ea:
Course: HIS 150G — History of Disabilities in East Asia
Credits: 5
Description: Many disabilities scholars and activists argue that categories and experiences of disability are socially constructed in important ways. Course examines changes over time in how disabilities have been perceived and lived in premodern and modern East Asia. Drawing on textual, visual, and oral sources, differences are explored between China, Japan, and Korea but also regional connections. Course also analyzes how disability has been intertwined with material and social factors constructing gender, class, and race or ethnicity.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 151 — Keywords in the History of Sci:
Course: HIS 151 — Keywords in the History of Science and Medicine
Credits: 5
Description: This five-week intensive course explores how scientific and medical terminology has evolved over three millennia, examining how ordinary-seeming words like "technology," "drug," and "robot" emerged from complex social and intellectual histories. Students investigate how terms traveled across languages and cultures, from ancient Greek techne to medieval Arabic alchemy to modern genetics, revealing the global nature of scientific knowledge. Through hands-on activities, primary source analysis, and engagement with current scientific discourse, students develop skills in tracing how the language we use shapes what we knowâand what we think we knowâabout science and medicine. The course is particularly relevant for students interested in history, science and technology studies, and global and community health. (Formerly History of Science, Medicine, and Technology from Antiquity to the Enlightenment.)
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 151A — Medicine and the Body in the:
Course: HIS 151A — Medicine and the Body in the Colonial World
Credits: 5
Description: Explores the histories of bodies and medicine in the colonial world. Charts the relationships among ideas about the body, medical practice, race, and labor in the colonial world between the 16th and the mid-20th centuries
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 151B — Drugs in World History:
Course: HIS 151B — Drugs in World History
Credits: 5
Description: What were drugs in the early modern world? Who grew and consumed them? How were they used, and why? Students study how humanity's ancient fascination with altered states shaped globalization, the Scientific Revolution, the Atlantic slave trade, colonialism, and modernity itself.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 154 — Post-Colonial North Africa:
Course: HIS 154 — Post-Colonial North Africa
Credits: 5
Description: Introduces the history of modern North Africa from WWI to the so-called Arab Spring. Topics include the dynamics of colonial rule and reform, anti-colonial nationalism, decolonization, the rise of Islamism, and popular protest.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 155 — History of Modern Israel:
Course: HIS 155 — History of Modern Israel
Credits: 5
Description: The conflict between Israelis and Palestinians is one of the most intractable disputes in our troubled world. Course begins with a glimpse of Palestine in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, surveys the rise and fall of utopian Zionism, pays especially close attention to the events of 1948 and 1967, and concludes by analyzing the collapse of hopes for peace after Oslo and Camp David meetings.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 156 — Interrogating Politics in the:
Course: HIS 156 — Interrogating Politics in the Post-Colonial Middle East
Credits: 5
Description: Explores the political trajectory of the post-colonial Middle East. Topics include: the Cold War and rise of Third Worldism; women's movements; political Islam; Arab-Israeli conflict; Lebanese Civil War; impact of oil production; Iranian Revolution; rise of the Arabian Gulf.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 156A — Art, Culture, and Mass Media:
Course: HIS 156A — Art, Culture, and Mass Media in the Arab Middle East
Credits: 5
Description: Chronicles the cultural history of the Arabic-speaking regions of the Middle East through art, literature, cinema, and mass media during the 20th and 21st Centuries.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 156B — Modern Arab Thought:
Course: HIS 156B — Modern Arab Thought
Credits: 5
Description: Studies the intellectual history of the Arab world from the nineteenth century to the Arab Spring. Beginning with Arab responses to colonialism, it covers the evolution of various schools of thought including liberalism, Islamism, Marxism, nationalism, and feminism.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 156C — Living Egyptian History in th:
Course: HIS 156C — Living Egyptian History in the City of Cairo
Credits: 5
Description: Traces the history of the Egyptian capital of Cairo beginning with the establishment of the city following its conquest by Arab armies in the seventh century and ending in our contemporary moment. Through a deep engagement with space and place, course considers how Cairo evolved throughout different political regimes, what the influence of politics has been on life and space in the city, and how the meaning and experience of urban space has changed over centuries.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 157 — The Ottoman Empire:
Course: HIS 157 — The Ottoman Empire
Credits: 5
Description: Explores the history of the Ottoman Empire with emphasis on its Arabic-speaking provinces. In addition to critically considering the political trajectory of the empire, we interrogate a wide range of topics relating to community organization, economic networks, international affairs, and the significance of religion within the Ottoman realm.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 158A — The Escapes of David George::
Course: HIS 158A — The Escapes of David George: Biographical Research on Slavery and Early America
Credits: 5
Description: Invites student collaboration on a biography of David George, born enslaved in colonial Virginia. His attempts to escape slavery led to a remarkable odyssey throughout the Atlantic World, revealing the constraints of slavery and limits of American freedom. (Formerly COWL 161C.)
Requirements: Requirements Enrollment is restricted to College Scholars.
courses.HIS 158C — Slavery in the Atlantic World:
Course: HIS 158C — Slavery in the Atlantic World: Historical and Archaeological Perspectives
Credits: 5
Description: Explores the African diaspora resulting from the transatlantic slave trade, drawing on methodologies from two academic disciplines--history and archaeology. Examines key questions about the slave system, using an array of source materials, both written documents and artifacts.
Requirements: Requirements Enrollment is restricted to proposed and declared history, anthropology, and critical race and ethnic studies majors and minors, and Black studies minors, during first-pass enrollment. Open to all students at the start of second-pass enrollment.
courses.HIS 158D — The Atlantic Slave Trade, 152:
Course: HIS 158D — The Atlantic Slave Trade, 1520-1866
Credits: 5
Description: Examines the largest forced migration in human history. From the 16th to 19th centuries, slave traders forced more than 12 million African people aboard ships departing Africa to supply enslaved labor to locations throughout the Americas. Course uses quantitative and qualitative methods to investigate this inhuman human migration with an emphasis on the experiences of the captives, the motives and profits of the empires and traders, the importance of slavery to colonial projects, and the resistance of enslaved people and free abolitionists.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 159A — Cleopatra to Constantine: Gre:
Course: HIS 159A — Cleopatra to Constantine: Greek and Roman Egypt
Credits: 5
Description: Examines the political, social, religious, and material culture of ancient Egypt during these periods of intense interaction with the ancient Near East and Mediterranean, from the period of Alexander (332 BCE) through the beginning of Coptic Christianity (3rd century CE).
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 159B — Women and Gender in Ancient E:
Course: HIS 159B — Women and Gender in Ancient Egypt
Credits: 5
Description: Explores sex and gender in ancient Egypt with a specific focus on women. Artistic representations, texts, objects of daily life, and burials are used to examine the practices that encoded gender in this ancient culture.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 159C — Temple and City: The Egyptian:
Course: HIS 159C — Temple and City: The Egyptian New Kingdom and the City of Thebes
Credits: 5
Description: Introduces the political and religious history of the Egyptian New Kingdom (1546-1086 BCE), using the city of Thebes as a focal point The political, religious, and architectural history of the city is covered.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 159D — When Cities Were New: the Ris:
Course: HIS 159D — When Cities Were New: the Rise of Urbanism in the Ancient Near East and Mediterranean
Credits: 5
Description: Investigates the rise and development of urbanism in the ancient Near East and Mediterranean world, including Mesopotamia, Syria, Egypt, Greece, and the Roman Empire. Close studies of individual ancient cities, as well as broader issues in ancient urbanism are covered.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 160A — Athenian Democracy:
Course: HIS 160A — Athenian Democracy
Credits: 5
Description: Athenian democracy from foundation to the fourth century B.C., with emphasis on its practices and ideologies. Readings from ancient sources and modern theory. Topics to include foundations and development; Athenian concepts of freedom, equality, law, citizenship. Lectures and discussion.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 160C — Topics in Greek History:
Course: HIS 160C — Topics in Greek History
Credits: 5
Description: Detailed consideration of some specific topic or period in Greek history, varying from year to year. Examples include Greek religion, Alexander, the Hellenistic world, the ancient Greek economy, and Greece and India; Thucydides and the Peloponnesian War; Greek art and archaeology.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.HIS 161B — Topics in Roman History:
Course: HIS 161B — Topics in Roman History
Credits: 5
Description: Detailed consideration of some specific topic or period in Roman history, varying from year to year. Examples include Roman religion, Augustus and the Roman Empire, Julio-Claudian emperors and the principate, Roman slavery, and Christianity and Rome.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.HIS 163B — Genesis: A History:
Course: HIS 163B — Genesis: A History
Credits: 5
Description: Introduction to historical, textual, source, and redaction criticism of the book of Genesis and to exegesis as science and ideology. Texts, history, and iconography of neighboring traditions (Mesopotamian, Ugaritic, Egyptian, Greek) are also studied when appropriate.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 163C — Jesus in History and Film:
Course: HIS 163C — Jesus in History and Film
Credits: 5
Description: In Roman Judea, a Jewish religious leader named Jesus was born during the reign of Herod the Great and executed under Pontius Pilate. Course focuses on the historical figure Jesus of Nazareth and the stories people have told about him, past and present. Also examines the ever-changing interpretations of Jesus, exploring the interpretive relationship between the ancient sources and the multiple efforts to narrate his life in film.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 165A — Medieval History and Architec:
Course: HIS 165A — Medieval History and Architecture
Credits: 5
Description: Covers the history and architecture of Europe and the Mediterranean from Late Antiquity through the fall of Constantinople in 1453. Beginning with Constantine and the rise of Christianity, this course follows the development and spread of new cultures and architectural forms, stretching from Islamic material in the east to the British Isles in the west. Course stresses the evolution of architecture during the medieval period as well as the cross-cultural influences that affected their form and what this can tell us about the cultures that created them.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 166 — Northern Ireland: Communities:
Course: HIS 166 — Northern Ireland: Communities in Conflict
Credits: 5
Description: Introduction to the so-called troubles in Northern Ireland, from the 1960s to the present. Examination of the historical background to the conflict, the patterns of conflict in the 1970s and 1980s, and the emergence of a peace process in the 1990s.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 167A — The First World War:
Course: HIS 167A — The First World War
Credits: 5
Description: An intensive analysis of the First World War from multiple perspectives: military, diplomatic, political, economic, technological, global, and cultural. The emphasis is on the transformative impact of the war on European societies, international relations, and modern culture.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 167B — The Second World War in Europ:
Course: HIS 167B — The Second World War in Europe
Credits: 5
Description: Making use of multiple perspectives, this course explores the origins of the Second World War, its course and outcome, and its transformative effects on European society, culture, polities, and demographics. Closely examines the war's impact on diverse civilian populations.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 169 — Dutch and Belgian History, 150:
Course: HIS 169 — Dutch and Belgian History, 1500 to Present
Credits: 5
Description: The political, social, economic, and cultural history of the modern Netherlands and Belgium from 1500 to the present day.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.HIS 170A — French History: Old Regime an:
Course: HIS 170A — French History: Old Regime and Revolution
Credits: 5
Description: French history from the Middle Ages through the Revolution. Focus on the rise and fall of absolute monarchy, the nature of Old Regime society, the causes and significance of the French Revolution. Attention to those who endured as well as to those who made events.
